snippet: A cease-fire plan was teetering, with the Syrian government making new demands, the opposition ridiculing them as unrealistic, and no sign that Syria’s military forces had withdrawn from cities.
abstract: Syrian peace plan brokered by the United Nations appears to be on its last legs, as Syria disregards the initial step of returning its security forces to their barracks and senior diplomats around the world recognize that a cease-fire is unlikely.

byline.original: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR and RICK GLADSTONE
byline.contributor: Neil MacFarquhar reported from Beirut, and Rick Gladstone from New York. Reporting was contributed by Sebnem Arsu from Ankara, Turkey; Alan Cowell from London; Hala Droubi from Beirut; Ellen Barry from Moscow; and a reporter for The New York Times from Damascus, Syria.

lead_paragraph: A cease-fire plan was teetering, with the Syrian government making new demands, the opposition ridiculing them as unrealistic, and no sign that Syria’s military forces had withdrawn from cities.

headline.seo: Violence in Syria Ahead of Cease-Fire
headline.main: Tensions Mount as Syria Truce Seems Elusive
headline.print_headline: Tensions Mounting in Syria as Cease-Fire Appears Increasingly Unlikely

keywords.value: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
